Authors: Chen Ren, Yu Hong, Long Wang, Qin-Er Yang
Title:
Generic recircumscription of Parasenecio (Asteraceae:
Senecioneae) based on nuclear ribosomal and plastid DNA sequences, with
descriptions of two new genera
Journal: Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society
Keywords:
East Asia  Miricacalia  Sinacalia  Syneilesis 
Tussilagininae
Abstract:
Parasenecio with c. 70 species is a major component of the
eastern Asian Tussilagininae (Asteraceae, Senecioneae). Previous
molecular phylogenetic studies, although with limited taxon sampling,
have suggested that it is polyphyletic and forms a complex with ten
other eastern Asian genera of Tussilagininae, i.e. the
LigulariaCremanthodium Parasenecio (LCP) complex. Here we sample
Parasenecio and its relatives in the LCP complex densely and generate
two phylogenetic hypotheses for the genus using four plastid DNA
(trnCGCA-petN, trnGUCC-trnTGGU-psbD, trnTUGUtrnLUAA and rpl32-ndhF) and
two nuclear ribosomal (nr)DNA [internal and external transcribed spacer
(ITS and ETS)] regions, respectively. Analyses of the plastid DNA data
produce a robust generic-level phylogenetic tree for Parasenecio and
clearly demonstrate the polyphyletic pattern of the genus. Most notably,
two sections of Parasenecio, P. section Delphiniifolii s.s. and P.
section Taimingasa, are shown to be distantly related to core
Parasenecio, being sister to Miricacalia and Syneilesis, respectively,
with strong support. The small genus Sinacalia is also revealed to be
polyphyletic, with S. caroli nested in core Parasenecio, and S.
tangutica and S. davidii forming a clade sister to the core
ParasenecioS. caroli clade. The nrDNA tree is, however, relatively
poorly resolved, only confirming the sister relationship between P.
section Delphiniifolii s.s. and Miricacalia. Sinacalia s.s. is resolved
as being deeply nested in core Parasenecio with nrDNA data, which is the
only significant incongruence with the plastid DNA hypothesis relevant
to the generic circumscription of Parasenecio. Statistical topology
(approximately unbiased and Swofford OlsenWaddellHillis) tests suggest
that, except for the position of Sinacalia s.s., the generic-level
relationships of Parasenecio inferred from the plastid DNA data are not
incongruent with those from the nrDNA data and, on the basis of current
sequence data, the inferred molecular phylogenetic relationships should
be preferred over the current classification. Based on these results and
evidence from morphology and karyology, we propose a new circumscription
of Parasenecio, involving transferring S. caroli to Parasenecio as P.
caroli comb. nov. and segregating P. section Delphiniifolii s.s. and P.
section Taimingasa as the new genera Japonicalia gen. nov. and
Taimingasa gen. nov., respectively. Sinacalia s.s., with significant
incongruence between the plastid DNA and nrDNA trees, is tentatively
retained as an independent genus pending future studies. A revised key
to Parasenecio and its close relatives is provided.
